snippet: In seeking authorization for a campaign against ISIS, President Obama took the unusual step of asking Congress to restrict the ability of the commander in chief to wage war, but he left room for flexibility.
abstract: News Analysis; Pres Obama's proposal for military campaign against Islamic State includes unusual request for Congress to impose three-year limit on action, but resolution's language leaves loopholes; contradictory move, which many say exemplifies Obama's overall strategy, fires debate between Republicans who say there are too many limits and liberal Democrats who say Obama has left too much room for flexibility.

byline.contributor: Emmarie Huetteman and Ashley Parker contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: In seeking authorization for a campaign against ISIS, President Obama took the unusual step of asking Congress to restrict the ability of the commander in chief to wage war, but he left room for flexibility.

headline.print_headline: A Dual View of War Power
headline.main: Obama’s Dual View of War Power Seeks Limits and Leeway
